About pi. I find it funny that people say that one can calculate the periphery of a circle but not of an ellipse when the periphery of circle is 2*pi*r and ellipse is 4*a*E(e), where r is the radius of the circle, a is the larger semiaxis of the ellipse and e is the excentricity of the ellipse. pi and E(e) are both as difficult to calculate exactly but somehow people say that the other equation is explicit and the other is not.

I find this course especially a great one. Probably many people will argue that it seems easy, the professor speaks slowly, many concepts are probably studied in high school, and is worried about the critical points in his explanation. And that's the point.. In one of this lectures the students asks more questions than in the complete calculus course I took in mi Spanish university 25 years ago.  In my course the professor took for granted much concepts that we didn't had, taught for himself (he was a mathematician of course, but we were studying chemistry..), worried more of finishing the lesson in time (at full speed) without taking into account the main key points of confusion a first year college has. I know there's a more theoretical (for mathematicians) courses of calculus in MIT, more formal and pure mathematics, but this is the best calculus course a first year college should have.

37:20 Define H(x) := F(x) - G(x), then H(b) - H(a)/ b-a = H'(c) for at least one c in (a,b) by MVT. Since H'(x) = F'(x) - G'(x) and F'(x) = G'(x) we have H'(x) = 0 and therefore H(x) = constant, i.e. F(x) = G(x) + constant.
VERY crappy,  A WASTE OF TIME, and i spent too much hours in this lecture but still cannot get in.

Take (f(x) - g(x))' which is equal to f'(x) - g'(x), which is equal to 0 using our given information. So, we can make a function, say h(x) = f(x) - g(x). And if we look at any interval in this function, every point in that interval will have derivative 0, so we can make any interval and the average slope will be 0 by MVT. Therefore, delta h / delta x will be 0, and delta x is not zero (since we aren't dealing with infinitesimals in the MVT), so delta h must be 0. Therefore, h(x) isn't changing, and whatever is the starting value of h(x) = f(x) - g(x) is (let's say c, since it can be any constant), is going to stay the value of h(x) for all x.  He said we need MVT for this because we can use it to conclude something about f(b) and f(a) without directly using the derivative, which is a limit and not an actual value in theory. FYI, I used f(x) to refer to F(x) and f'(x) to refer to F'(x) in my explanation.

Courses at MIT are given numbers. The number before the period denotes which subject/school the course is from. Anything course 18 (18.xxx) is from Mathematics. 18.01 is single variable calculus, 18.02 is multivariable calculus. See http://catalog.mit.edu/subjects/ for more info on the course numbers. Best wishes on your studies!

I find this opinion genuinely interesting because David made everything clear to me. Very curious how different people can be. In fact I think he really simplified ideas a great deal. I've seen much more complicated explanations of the concepts not just in this video but the whole lecture series. Sometimes, unlike Jerison, professors don't even explain the concepts in class at all.

I'd like to know how you might explain the concepts simpler. In my opinion his explanations proceeded in very logical steps. I hope you're not confusing complexity for rigor (not that these lectures are that rigorous to begin with). You can develop an intuitive understanding of maths concepts without really having a solid foundation for believing in why the ideas are correct. On the other hand you can go deep into why they are correct but that doesn't mean you're overcomplicating it. You're investigating more about it.

These video lectures of Professor David Jerison teaching 18.01 were recorded live in the Fall of 2007 and do not correspond precisely to the lectures taught in the Fall of 2006 (e.g., the lecture notes). For more information, see the course on MIT OpenCourseWare at: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-01F06. We also strongly recommend an improved version of this course: http://ocw.mit.edu/18-01SCF10. Best wishes on your studies!
Mattrix Shreshth It’s a Latin phrase that basically means “proven”. Search it up :)
From the Latin "Integralis", it literally means "The whole". It makes sense, as it is a sum of a bunch of terms.

"Q.E.D." (sometimes written "QED") is an abbreviation for the Latin phrase "quod erat demonstrandum" ("that which was to be demonstrated"), a notation which is often placed at the end of a mathematical proof to indicate its completion.
actually sometime it is also used to say "Quiet Easily Done"

avatarmage34 Well procedural mathematics does not fascinate me if I don't understand a fair amount of theory behind it. It will not satisfy me to be able to differentiate or integrate but not understand what it means to do so. You could always learn a bunch of procedural rules to manipulate symbols which in actual fact bears no meaning at all. When you start to apply mathematics to real problems (I mean in engineering or other disciplines, not framed as mathematical problems) without knowing what to apply beforehand then your true understanding is tested.I have tried Khan Academy, and Khan does in fact go through more by examples but I find sometimes it gets things done but leaves me wondering what it all even means anyway. Vague analogies only give superficial understanding.

ALL of the terms between N and 1, which I substituted for the endpoints b and a, sorry tht was confusing. anyway, all the terms between there cancel out. and were left with just the terms at the end.

then we basically have a bunch of rectangles. when n approaches infinity, the rectangles width gets infinity small, and the values for f(x) over that interval pretty much become equal, they differ very little. so we can multiple f(x) by the differential dx, the very small width, and get the anti derivtive of each one of the rectangles. the sum then becomes of a bunch of rectangles, and is now the following. [F(n)-F(n-1)] + [F(n-1) - F(n-2)] ...-[F(2) - F(1)]. THEN, the amazing part....

Im kind of disappointed to see that at no point during this did he make the connection between WHY the integral from a to b of f(x) equals its antiderivative of F(b)-F(a). Basically, why does the area under the curve only appear to depend on its end points? this always confused me during calculus, because the answer isnt very obvious, but its stunning whats you see the conneciton. using riemann sums as well, at some number b-a/n as n goes to infinity.

@Notyouranalyst  He's referring to the integral. So far in this calculus course, we examine an integral and know the antiderivative in terms of functions we've seen before, known also as "elementary functions". There is no elementary function that exists as the antiderivative of f(x) = exp(-x^2). Another way to put this along the lines of the lecture: What (elementary) function can we write whose derivative is exp(-x^2)? We can't. Instead, we operate with d/dx on the integral of exp(-t^2) with respect to t between the limits of 0 and x and that "washes away" the constant represented by the lower integration limit. (This isn't a rigorous demonstration; it's only the way to perform a computation. The FTC2 supports us.)
